Award.AwardTitle: Structure of water at interfaces with nanometer solutes and bioenergetics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Dmitry Matyushov of Arizona State University is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Chemistry Division to develop theoretical methods to study the structure and dynamics of the protein-water interface. The main focus of this research is on the connection between electrostatic properties of hydrated proteins and efficiency of electron transport in biology. Redox proteins are employed by living systems to transport electrons across the cellular membrane. This process is a major step in the overall bioenergetics of the cell. The fundamental efficiency bottleneck of energy chains of biology is rooted in the conflicting requirements of long-distance electron transport and low energy input. Results from Matyushov's research group offer a potential resolution to this conundrum, providing a connection between sequence and fold of proteins, dictated by selection, and their function as electron carriers. The PI has proposed that protein-water interfaces have developed to produce the statistics and dynamics of electrostatic fluctuations distinct from those observed for small molecules. Globular redox proteins are studied to clarify the origin of their unusual electrostatic properties. Theories of non-Gaussian interfacial fluctuations are being developed and tested against numerical computer simulations and laboratory experiments.


The structure of water at the nanometer interface is of broad importance for the understanding of life. All energy of life depends on efficient trans-membrane electron transport, either in photosynthetic reaction centers or mitochondria. The problems addressed by this proposal will affect a number of disciplines where water-mediated interactions are critical. The proposed work integrates with educational effort to establish a program in theoretical biological physics/chemistry, including the development of undergraduate and graduate courses, weekly seminars, poster sessions, and annual workshops.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Creation of biological energy by living organisms by absorbing sunlight (photosynthesis) or by transforming organic matter in mitochondria of animals is a central problem for cellular biology and for our overall understanding of the principles of life. General to all these physiological processes is cross-membrane transport of electrons that eventually creates the cross-membrane potential driving all biochemical reactions. Electron transport must be accomplished with a small input of energy and even smaller loss of energy. Synthetic systems have not been able to achieve this kind of efficiency so far and one wants to understand what is specific about proteins that resolves the energy bottleneck.

Cross-membrane electron transport is strongly affected by electrostatic interactions with the water shell surrounding proteins and membranes. Understanding of the catalytic activity of electron transfer proteins and of enzymes in general thus requires reliable knowledge of the physical properties of the protein-water interface. 

We have done a number of theoretical studies in this project to understand the spread (spectrum) and time dependence (dynamics) of the electrostatic fluctuations of water surrounding objects of nanometer size. Electrostatic fluctuations strongly affect the rates of reactions catalyzed by proteins. It turned out that water in the nanometer interface tends to split in polarized domains, similar to those found in bulk ferroelectric materials (relaxor ferroelectrics). This physical mechanism is largely responsible for the observed spectrum and dynamics of the interfacial fluctuations. We have also noticed that polarized domains extend significantly into the bulk. The estimates than show that most of so called "biological water" (i.e., intracellular water) has to be partially oriented water.

The movement of the surface domains occurs on relatively long time-scales and, additionally, on a number of different time-scales. The wide spread of time-scales involved (dispersive dynamics) opens a number of unusual opportunities for the enzyme catalysis, which can be specified as the dynamical control of the reaction rate. The essence of this idea is that when the reaction becomes slower than some of the relaxation processes, the activation barrier gains a dependence on the dynamics. This is usually not observed in less complex catalytic compounds, such as those synthesized in the lab, and can be viewed as a characteristic signature of complex interfaces, such as the protein-water interface. This observation implies that evolution of the protein enzymetic activity might have gone into selection of both the favorable thermodynamic and dynamic properties and, in particular, into matching between the reaction rate and the dynamics of interfacial fluctuations. These novel findings offer a shift in the understanding of how enzymes work. 

The main outcome of the project is that the structure of the protein-water interface characteristic of all hydrated proteins is responsible for a broad spectrum of overall non-Gaussian electrostatic fluctuations at the protein active site. We have extended computer simulations of the membrane protein complexes into the range of tens of microseconds and confirmed that our observations on smaller systems and shorter trajectories stand against these new tests. The dynamical control of the rates of enzymetic reactions is a very general result, with a potential for broad applications in molecular biology, enzyme catalysis, and bioenergetics.
